title: The Choosing
outcome: Citizens discredit the BCI, holding free public assemblies at the mural to debate their future. Leadership shifts as the council must participate openly. The system’s legacy is preserved only for critical safety, while power moves to citizen-elected managers.

events.description: Citizen delegates gather at the mural, using open lotteries to select new representatives. Council members are compelled to answer questions directly in public, losing their usual privileges.
Assemblies debate the future of the BCI. As trust disappears, a consensus forms: BCI will remain only for essential safety coordination—everything else transitions to elected neighborhood committees.
Council votes internally to cede much of its power. Oksana Lintz and Rada Miskovic publicly announce the end of algorithmic rule over services and jobs, urging order during the transition.
Temporary confusion and disputes slow some services, but citywide morale rises. The mural becomes a symbol of open democracy as the new citizen councils take responsibility for organizing daily life.
